utterances: Our customers have to agree that they're going to foot that bill.
A few years ago, his company built a small-scale, temporary project that captured and stored carbon dioxide at a big West Virginia plant.
It worked.

But when the company asked to build a larger version and pass on the costs, state regulators said no. Akins says companies like his aren't planning to build coal-fired power plants anyway - natural gas and wind are affordable right now.
But that could change, and he worries that because of EPA's new proposal, coal would no longer be an option.
To the lay person, it would say that the EPA is trying to stop all coal development.
Akins' bigger concern is the EPA's next job - promised regulations to limit greenhouse gas emissions from existing power plants.
Environmentalists are also reacting to today's proposal, which comes 18 months after the original.
The EPA says this version will stand up better against anticipated legal attacks.
But Vickie Patton, chief lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, says the EPA is just losing time.

The sooner we get these protections in place, the clearer the signal is: New power plants must do their fair share at addressing the heavy burden of carbon pollution on human health and the environment.
She says like increases in extreme weather events.
Patton lives in Boulder, Colo., where torrential rains last week destroyed houses and washed away roads.
Seven people died, and 10 more are presumed dead.
It's too early to say whether climate change played a role in Colorado's disaster.
But Patton says living through it makes her more impatient for the government to step in to reduce greenhouse gases.
Seeing close at hand the ravages of extreme weather, it only just underscores the urgency of action.
A final rule to cut greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants should come out in about a year.
Elizabeth Shogren.
NPR News, Washington.
NPR's business news starts with a U.K.
interest rate probe.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
The former chief executive of Barclays is testifying before a parliamentary committee in Britain.
Bob Diamond, who resigned yesterday, is being asked about the rate-setting scandal at the bank.
He told lawmakers in the hearing today that it was an unfortunate series of events.
Yesterday, Barclays released documents suggesting a Bank of England official may have pressured Barclays to lower its rates.
NPR's Jim Zarroli reports.

Our NHL players, every last one of the American team and NHL player lost four of six games, and they were eliminated from the medal round today.

The Canadian team, also all NHLers, did not acquit itself terribly well in the opening round, and Finland and Slovakia -- the two best teams -- they've got a lot of NHL players too, and the question that comes up in my mind now is: Is it worth it to have NHL over there?
It's great hockey.
You do get a disadvantage with a couple of teams that just don't have as many NHL players, and I wonder, maybe it was more fun when the amateurs were playing.
So the women's hockey team, by winning a bronze, actually did better than the men's hockey team.
They did, but this is a giant disappointment.

women and the Canadian women - up until the other night when America lost - had not lost a single game against any other country other than each other, more than 200 games that they had played.

Nordic combined, Stefan.

There were four American reporters at this event that I attended in the mountains yesterday.

You're saying that curling is seven times more popular than what is normally MSNBC or whatever it is - CNBC.
It's CNBC, and it says something about who's watching Business News late in the afternoon.
Okay, Stefan, last thoughts about Turin, the Olympic Games of 2006.
The problem becomes that the U.S.

Committee is deciding more and more how much to spend on these events based on how the athletes finished, and when the results can be as quirky as they are in these winter pursuits, it's disappointing for a lot of these sports to fall short and to end up with less money down the road.
Stefan, thank you so much for talking us today and before.
Thanks, Robert.
Stefan Fatsis of the Wall Street Journal talks with us on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED, usually on Fridays but not always, about sports and the business of sports.
If you're spending record amounts to fill your gas tank, just imagine what it costs to fill a big-rig truck.
And then imagine what the cost of shipping food and other goods across the country will do to the prices you pay in the store.
Today, hundreds of truck drivers are rallying on Capitol Hill to protest the high diesel prices that are eating away at their profits.
In a few minutes, we'll speak with our economics expert Keith Reed about the impact the trucking industry has on our economy.
But right now, we have trucker Delbert Langston.
He's an independent driver who owns and operates his own vehicle.
Welcome, Delbert.
Good afternoon.
How are you?
So, Delbert, how long have you been driving?
I've been an owner/operator for three years now.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of basically running your own shop?
You get the chance to pick and choose where you want to go, is one of the biggest advantages.
Less problematic with dealing with people other than the person you pick it up from, the shipper and who you deliver it to, your consignee.
There's nobody in between that you really have to mess with while you out there driving.
So, you're kind of on your own.
So it gives you a sense of freedom.
Are you feeling the hit, economically?
Oh, very much so.
Very much so.
In the last year, I've seen my fuel costs go up as much as 600-plus a week extra.
Yeah, and that's out of your pocket.
Well let me bring in Keith Reed.

He's a reporter for the Cincinnati Enquirer, writes a finance blog for BET called ""Dollar Out of 15 Cents."" Now, Keith, you join us every now and then, and you've heard a little bit of Delbert's story.
He's not alone.
You've got this big protest going on in Washington today with the truckers gathering to protest the prices.
From your standpoint, Keith, is there really anything the government could do right now to ease prices for truckers?
That's a very difficult question, Farai.
I think, on the one hand, there are some things that the government could do, but it would be very difficult for the government to do those things.
I mean, the most obvious thing that I think could happen is some talk of a moratorium, at least temporarily, on gas taxes that the states and the federal government put on.
As you know, gas taxes take up a significant percentage of the price of every gallon of gasoline that you put in your car or that truckers like Delbert put into their rigs.
The problem is that state governments, the federal government, depends on those revenues.
That would at best be a temporary fix, and selling that to a governor or a state legislature somewhere would be very, very difficult.
Outside of that, I don't know that there's really much that the government can do to bring some immediate relief to truckers and to drivers at this point.
Delbert, who would you like to help you?
I mean, when you think about this, and you think about the fact, as we mentioned, that there were some truckers who were gathering to protest these prices...

I need to thank the bosses who decided to start this show and to sustain it over more than two decades.

I need to thank the member stations, and not just the more than 400 who carried this program, but all of them, all those stations who collectively support NPR and allow us to borrow their outlets to talk with people across the country.
And I need to thank you.
We're told that more than 3.6 million of you listen each week.
That puts TALK OF THE NATION in the top 10 of all talk shows in the country.
The currency of broadcasting is that number, the quantity of eyes and ears that can be delivered to soap manufacturers and carmakers.
To be honest, we do a little bit of that on public radio, as well.
But on TALK OF THE NATION in particular, listeners have voices, too.

This program works best when we find ways to engage your stories about your jobs and your kids, you fears and your successes, about what happened in the drought, the hurricane, in the fire, in the hospital, at the job and at school, in Iraq or Vietnam.
Over all my time at NPR, I worked as a reporter, editor and producer.
And as much as I loved all those jobs, the past 11-and-a-half years, this job has been the best.
It's been an honor to talk with you every day.
600 weeks.
Give away time off for vacation, throw in all the special coverage, let's round it off at 5,000 hours.
There is still so much to talk about, but that's going to have to be enough.
